Dmitri Prokofitch Razumihin," she said, introducing him to Luzhin. 

"I met him yesterday," Pyotr Petrovitch mumbled, giving Razumihin a mean look. Then he frowned and stayed quiet. 

Pyotr Petrovitch was the kind of person who seemed very polite in public but got really upset if things didn’t go his way. When that happened, he acted more like a sack of flour than a lively person. 

The room fell silent again. Raskolnikov wouldn’t speak, and Avdotya Romanovna didn’t want to start talking too soon. Razumihin had nothing to say, so Pulcheria Alexandrovna felt nervous again. 

"Have you heard that Marfa Petrovna is dead?" she started, trying to bring up a topic. 

"Yes, I heard. I was told right away. I came to let you know that Arkady Ivanovitch Svidrigaïlov rushed to Petersburg right after his wife’s funeral. I believe this from a good source," he replied. 

"To Petersburg? Here?" Dounia asked, worried, looking at her mother. 

"Yes, and he probably has a reason for coming so quickly, considering everything that happened before," he said. 

"Good heavens! Will he not leave Dounia alone even here?" Pulcheria Alexandrovna exclaimed.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Pyotr Petrovitch's polite demeanor masks his discomfort and hostility towards Razumihin as they discuss the recent death of Marfa Petrovna and the arrival of Svidrigaïlov in Petersburg.
